clinical_study.brief_title: Influence of the Initial Level of Consciousness on Early, Goal-directed Mobilization
clinical_study.official_title: Influence of the Initial Level of Consciousness on Early, Goal-directed Mobilization

brief_summary.textblock: Analysis of the randomized controlled SOMS trial of early, goal-directed mobilization to investigate if the treatment effect is consistent and independent of the initial conscious state without evidence of moderation or modification.

primary_outcome.time_frame: At the day of hospital discharge, on average up to 1 month
primary_outcome.description: minimal modified functional independence measure score of 8 (Scale ranging from 0-8 with the subdomain locomotion and transfer 0-4 each)

secondary_outcome.measure: average achieved mobility level during the ICU stay
secondary_outcome.time_frame: from ICU admission to ICU discharge, on average up to 2 weeks
At the day of hospital discharge, on average up to 1 month
secondary_outcome.description: minimal modified functional independence measure score (range 0-8) of the subdomains transfer and locomotion with 0-4 each

secondary_outcome.time_frame: Days from ICU admission till first mobilization, approximately up to 5 days
secondary_outcome.description: Start to mobilization in days (Surgical Optimal Mobilization Scale > 0, ranging from 0 = no mobilization to 4 ambulation)

arm_group.description: Early goal-directed mobilization with (1) SOMS algorithm and (2) facilitator

intervention.description: Early, goal directed mobilization using (1) the SOMS algorithm and (2) facilitator

criteria.textblock:
Inclusion Criteria:
- aged 18 years or older
- mechanically ventilated for less than 48 h and expected to require mechanical ventilation for at least another 24 h at the time of screening
- functionally independent at baseline with a Barthel Index Score of at least 70 at 2 weeks before admission to the ICU based on patient or proxy completion of the measure
Exclusion Criteria:
- admitted to hospital for more than 5 days before screening
- a motor component of Glasgow Coma Scale (GCS) lower than 5
- irreversible disorder with a 6-month mortality of greater than 50%,
- raised intracranial pressure
- cardiopulmonary arrest
- unstable fractures contributing to probable immobility
- inclusion in another trial at the same time
- acute myocardial infarction
- do not have lower part of their legs
- have a rapidly developing neuromuscluar disease
- pregnant
- ruptured or leaking aortic aneurysm
